markdownRemark.html:
I won’t pretend I am the biggest The Dillinger Escape Plan (TDEP) fan in the world. I have probably listened to roughly 80% of their discography. But I was enraptured by their unique style that sought to undo many of the comforts we have in conventional song-writing and musicianship.

Some years ago I was playing a video game called Bioshock in which you — the protagonist — crash land in the middle of the ocean in the opening chapter. The cause of your misfortune is not disclosed. The still floating, burning wreckage that was your plane is slowly sinking and so you are encourage to alight. Into the waters. Fortunately a tower in the middle of the ocean is within swimming distance, and it is your only hope for survival. After dragging your apparently capable self out of the ocean waters your enter the tower. From here things get pretty crazy. An elevator takes you to an undersea city where the brightest scientific minds have created a safe haven for pushing the limits of what humanity can achieve. Unfettered by the scrupulous.
